awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Deep Learning Classifier Using Hyper Spectral Imaging for Automated Processing of Fish Fillets
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to advance the development of solutions for the fish processing industry. Current fish fillet preparation depends highly on visual inspection and manual trimming by trained technicians to identify and remove blemishes and food-borne parasites, which remain a significant cost of seafood preparation. Preparation of seafood by hand also poses significant health risks for consumers. The presence of human technicians means significant portions of seafood processing must be performed at room temperature, increasing the risk of bacterial infection and enzymatic degradation. This decreases the freshness and quality of the final product, while increasing chances of foodborne illness. Additionally, the manual detection rate for nematode infections can be as low as 50% under industrial conditions due to the small size of the infections and the potential depth in the fish. The proposed automated hyperspectral imaging (HSI)-based platform addresses these issues by (1) fully automating the complete fish processing supply/value chain, (2) obviating industry dependence on manual inspection and (3) being much less error-prone and more precise than manual inspection and trimming, reducing lost yield and promoting safer products for consumers. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will advance the development of a hyperspectral imaging (HSI) system for the automatic processing and remediation of fish fillets. HSI has already been validated in the detection of anatomical features of fish fillets and detection of harmful parasites like nematodes. However, its use has not been validated on an industrial scale. The proposed research will focus on: (1) compilation and annotation of a fish fillet data set, (2) training and validation of deep learning algorithms to detect fish fillet center line and nematode infestations, and (3) assessing the feasibility of using a state-of-the-art robotic actuator and customizing it for automatic nematode removal with the company's novel algorithms. The result will be a computer vision platform capable of recognizing nematodes/other foodborne parasites, detecting blemishes, blood spots, and other undesirable cosmetic marks, as well as conducting precision removal of identified parasites and blemishes without excess loss of fish meat.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Fish fillet processing requires demanding visualization of complex features for highly precise trimming and portioning. Once caught, fish products must be filleted and inspected for the presence of foodborne parasites, pin bones, inedible features or defects. Current approaches to automating this process rely on expensive x-ray visualization equipment, effective for pin bone removal but cannot detect parasites and nematodes. As a result, final inspection requires human labor that is imprecise, prone to error and leads to seafood production bottlenecks and undetected parasites posing higher consumer health risks.

This project worked towards a novel technique combining hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and deep learning to effectively and inexpensively identify key fish fillet features, especially nematodes and parasites currently undetected by x-rays. We effectively reached our goals as we achieved a hyperspectral setup using Transflectance Cold Halogen Illumination and captured 950 fillets with it, labelling over 6,000 nematodes, and successfully developed a deep learning surpassing 80% recall.

As a result, we delivered a modular prototype for detecting nematodes on fish, with vision and sorting capacities that can be used for quality grading before manual processing, or quality control after manual processing.

The award of the NSF Phase II SBIR funding will allow us to develop the hardware components of the proposed machine, in particular the robotic nematode removal component conceptualized in Phase I and prepare for commercialization by ensuring manufacturability and cost efficiency of the hardware. Moreover, Phase II R&D efforts will focus on optimizing the machine learning approach defined during Phase I and on the development of a backend data platform for storage and processing of image data. Leveraging our strategic relationships with key opinion leaders in the fish processing industry, we aim to demonstrate the capabilities of our nematode detection and removal system through a field test in selected fish processing plants.


Last Modified: 06/14/2021
Modified by: Kristjan Ingvarsson
